issues.title: Not compiling
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
The draft is not automatically compiling on GitHub as it should. Seems like it has never compiled after moving to lake-wg

The draft (venue:) and readme markdown refered to the old repository. I fixed this, but some of the links in Readme.md does not work as it has never compiled on the new lake-wg repo.

(I fixed a few other things in the header like silencing a SVG warning and fixing my name.)

issues.title: IANA Considerations
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
Needs to add the PSK method to the "EDHOC Method Type Registry"

Needs to add a label to to the "EDHOC Exporter Label Registry" to be used for resumption

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Create new registry for info_labels. This was missed in RFC9528

issues.title: message_3 reveals the length of the PSK identifier and does not allow padding
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
```
Enc( ID_CRED_PSK ), AEAD( EAD_3 )

message_3 = (
  CIPHERTEXT_3A: bstr,
  CIPHERTEXT_3B: bstr,
)

```

message_3 reveals the length of the PSK identifier and does not allow padding. Padding is only supported in EAD_3

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Fixed in main

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body: Just a comment: my understanding is that now Appendix G.  Long PLAINTEXT_2 is applicable to Message_3 in EDHOC-PSK when enabling the encryption of ID_CRED_PSK and AEAD (EAD_3) with KEYSTREAM_3.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Done in main

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Fixed in main

issues.title: Resumption
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body: Specify how this is used for resumption

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Comment from Charlie Jacomme:

```
* should we make sure that a PSK derived from some EDHOC exchange with 
some ciphersuite SUITE can only be used for resumption with the 
corresponding SUITE or higher?
```
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/lake/IdMFc1kDqdGhg6GCvlo22dZmJp0/

I agree I think we should make sure that a PSK derived from some EDHOC exchange with 
some ciphersuite SUITE can only be used for resumption with the  corresponding SUITE.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: As we have identity protection we can allow reuse of the resumption key.

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body:
In the same way that TLS 1.3 does, we should explicitly distinguish between "external PSK" (the out-of-band PSK) and "resumption PSK"

Then adding the derivation of ID_CRED_PSK and rPSK . I think they should be derived from PRK_out.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
> In the same way that TLS 1.3 does, we should explicitly distinguish between "external PSK" (the out-of-band PSK) and "resumption PSK"

That is good terminology but I don't see any technical differences.

> Then adding the derivation of ID_CRED_PSK and rPSK . I think they should be derived from PRK_out.

Yes, just add add a couple of exporter labels.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Missing:
* Exporter label to derive PSK
* Exporter label to derive key identifier
* Distinction between I and R (see #14)
* Being able to switch roles (or why not)

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body: Regarding this part, at the beginning of security section we have a distinction between *Initial Handshake* and *Session Resumption*. In the session resumption part, I do not think we need to reuse the same ID_CRED_PSK and CRED_PSK for resumption PSK. Each time EDHOC-PSK is run a new PRK_Exporter will be generated, which means a new  (resumption) ID_CRED_PSK and CRED_PSK will be generated.

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body: And how would you derive the ID_CRED_PSK and the CRED_PSK from a PRK_exporter?

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body:
Could it be by using EDHOC_Expand? So say CRED_PSK = EDHOC_Expand(PRK_Exporter, label, context, length)?
And as for ID_CRED_PSK it could be derived from CRED_PSK?

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body:
Yes, that is why Göran annotated that we need an:

"Exporter label to derive PSK
Exporter label to derive key identifier"

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body:
And what would the context of the Expand function be in this case? 
And for the labels right now EDHOC only has 0, 1, so could it be 2 and 3 for CRED_PSK and ID_CRED_PSK?

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body:
According to 10.1.  EDHOC Exporter Label Registry (in RFC 9528) 2 an 3 would do (0 and 1 are assigned to OSCORE Master Secret and OSCORE Master Salt, respectively). About the context , we can the same as for deriving OSCORE Master Secret and Master Salt

rPSK = EDHOC_Exporter( 2, h'', resumption_psk_length )
rID_CRED_PSK   = EDHOC_Exporter( 3, h'', id_cred_psk_length )

I guess with "enough" id_cred_psk_length we can avoid any collision. I added "r" to distinguish from the PSK and ID_CRED_PSK but I do not know if this will be necessary

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body: I was wondering whether having a rID_CRED_PSK derived in this way might a be a problem. Since the responder does not choose the value, might be collision. To avoid that, as I mentioned, the rID_CRED_PSK should have "enough" length to reduce the probability of a collision but the drawback is that we may want to have a really short rID_CRED_PSK

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body: Another option for this  would be that the Responder chooses the new ID_CRED_PSK and include this in message_4. If the new ID_CRED_PSK is sent in message_4 , this also can signal that resumption PSK must be generated.

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body: I have added text for external PSK and resumption PSK

issues.title: Exact values of info_labels
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
```
KEYSTREAM_3 = EDHOC_KDF( PRK_3e2m, TBD1, TH_3, ID_CRED_PSK length )
K_3         = EDHOC_KDF( PRK_4e3m, TBD2, TH_3, key_length )
IV_3        = EDHOC_KDF( PRK_4e3m, TBD3, TH_3, iv_length )
```

TBD1 is a new value.

Is the info_labels for K_3 and IV_3 the same as in RFC 9528?

@gselander why do we not have a IANA registry for info_labels?

comments.author: emanjon

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: The values should have TBD1, TBD2, and TBD3. Need a IANA registry. This is handled in #3

comments.body: Reopening this. Since we are creating the registry we can assign these values 11, 12, 13 ourselves.

issues.title: New names for PLAINTEXT_2 and PLAINTEXT_3 to avoid colliding CDDL
issues.author: emanjon

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Changed to PLAINTEXT_2B and PLAINTEXT_3B in main.

(Not sure these are the optimal names, but that can be changed later)

issues.title: Diff vs self-contained document
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
The current specification is written as a diff against RFC 9528. This is good from an economy of specification and may be good for a person who is familiar with RFC 9528, which anyway is assumed. 

However, it is difficult to read when you need to have RFC 9528 open on the side, and it isn't clear which parts of RFC 9528 that are not used. Moreover, since some terms are given a different definition and/or a different interpretation, there is risk for both confusion and potential errors.

For readability, some parts may not be repeated. This has the drawback when there is a need for update.

We should not have contradicting CDDL definitions between this spec and RFC 9528.

Also, the labeling of the parameters becomes confusing when the original meaning is lost, e.g. the "2m" part of PRK_3e2m does mean anything when there is no MAC in message 2. 

I'm in favor of defining new terms that makes sense for the new protocol, but also indicate what parts carry over directly from RFC 9528. Some overall refactoring is needed to carry out this.

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body: I have added more explanations in the message formatting rather than just referring to RFC9528

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Good start, but we are not there yet. If you go through each term you'll find some disconnect with RFC 9528.

> TH_3 = H( TH_2, PLAINTEXT_2 )

There is no PLAINTEXT_2 in this draft

> KEYSTREAM_3 = EDHOC_KDF( PRK_3e2m, 11, TH_3, plaintext_length_3 )

plaintext_length_3 is not mentioned elsewhere in this draft, only plaintext_length. 

And if we inherit the definitions from RFC 9528, then plaintext_length refers to the parameter used to derive KEYSTREAM_2. But here it is used to derive KEYSTREAM_3.

Instead of using the term "plaintext_length" when describing the calculation of KEYSTREAM_2 it is stated: "The length of the keystream matches the expected length of PLAINTEXT_2B." Better copy and adapt the text from RFC 9528: "plaintext_length is the length of PLAINTEXT_2B".

I also noted (which I may be guilty of)
>  * KEYSTREAM_3 is used to encrypt the ID_CRED_PSK in message_3.

but this is only a partial description of what is encrypted. Either we remove this bullet or improve / reference its later definition.

I have not made a side-by-side comparison and may have missed other mismatches or reformulations between this draft and RFC 9528.

Morover, some terminology is not very intuitive in the draft:
PLAINTEXT_2B  -->  CIPHERTEXT_2
PLAINTEXT_3A  -->  CIPHERTEXT_3
PLAINTEXT_3B  -->  CIPHERTEXT_3B

How about, for example:
PLAINTEXT_2B  -->  CIPHERTEXT_2B
PLAINTEXT_3A  -->  CIPHERTEXT_3A
PLAINTEXT_3B  -->  CIPHERTEXT_3B

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body:
I made the following changes:
1.  TH_3 = H( TH_2, PLAINTEXT_2 ) --> TH_3 = H( TH_2, PLAINTEXT_2B )
2. KEYSTREAM_3 = EDHOC_KDF( PRK_3e2m, 11, TH_3, plaintext_length_3 ) --> added plaintext_length_3 is the length of PLAINTEXT_3A in message_3
3. Modified: plaintext_length is the length of PLAINTEXT_2B.
4. And I agree with the newer definition, it is indeed a bit more clear.

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body:
As for the PRK, I agree it may be better to redefine them. I can do that. It would be as follows:
1. PRK_2e --> same
2. PRK_3e2m --> PRK_3e
3. PRK_4e3m --> PRK_4e
4. SALT_3e2m --> SALT_3e
5. SALT_4e3m --> SALT_4e
6. KESYTREAM_2 --> KESYTREAM_2B??
7. KESYTREAM_3 --> KESYTREAM_3A??

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Yes, maybe. Then you may get plaintext_length_2B and plaintext_length_3B as well ... 

How much references to RFC 9528 do we have left then (in terms of definitions and equations)? 

How much of the processing can we still refer to RFC 9528, even if all / most definitions are made in this draft? 

It is a delicate balance before you need to repeat the steps with the new terminology. Without having tried I can't say if it is possible.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Also remember definition of PRK_out, and K_4, IV_4 if you change the namesof PRK_4e3m ...

Perhaps need to stop before you rename PRKs ...

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
And if we go for terminology revolution, then consider 2B --> 2A. In that case all things with label A in this draft is encrypted with XOR, which also simplifies the understanding. 

CIPHERTEXT_2A = PLAINTEXT_2A XOR KEYSTREAM_2  ( or KEYSTREAM_2A)
CIPHERTEXT_3A = PLAINTEXT_3A XOR KEYSTREAM_3  ( or KEYSTREAM_3A)

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
> I made the following changes:
> 
>     1. TH_3 = H( TH_2, PLAINTEXT_2 ) --> TH_3 = H( TH_2, PLAINTEXT_2B )
> 
>     2. KEYSTREAM_3 = EDHOC_KDF( PRK_3e2m, 11, TH_3, plaintext_length_3 ) --> added plaintext_length_3 is the length of PLAINTEXT_3A in message_3
> 
>     3. Modified: plaintext_length is the length of PLAINTEXT_2B.
> 
>     4. And I agree with the newer definition, it is indeed a bit more clear.

There is still one plaintext_length --> plaintext_length_3 change missing

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: I've read through and I think it works to read this as a diff compared to EDHOC. Closing this issue.

issues.title: Update title, abstract and intro
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
Some proposed updates:

* Title 

OLD
EDHOC PSK Authentication
NEW
EDHOC authenticated with Pre-Shared Keys

abbrev: "EDHOC PSK"

* Abstract

OLD
This document specifies the Pre-Shared Key (PSK) authentication method for the Ephemeral Diffie-Hellman Over COSE (EDHOC) key exchange protocol. It describes the authentication processes, message flows, and security considerations of this authentication method.

NEW
This document specifies an authentication method for the Ephemeral Diffie-Hellman Over COSE (EDHOC) key exchange protocol based on Pre-Shared Keys (PSK). This method may be used for initial authentication and for resumption based on secret keys derived from a previously established EDHOC session.

Also, mention identity protection.

* Intro

Remove GBA, AKMA is sufficient to mention. Replace text with EAP with text about 

EAP-EDHOC plan to use this for resumption, include a 
 reference.

issues.title: Privacy considerations
issues.author: gselander
issues.body: This section is empty. Should at least talk about identity protection.

issues.title: Section 8 is a security consideration
issues.author: gselander
issues.body: Make this section a subsection of Security considerations

issues.title: Reflection/selfie attacks
issues.author: emanjon
labels: MUST be solved before formal analysis
issues.body:
PSK authentication without identities is typically vulnerable to  reflection/Selfie attacks. Unless, we have some good reasons to believe that this is not the case we should probably mandate the inclusion of an identityin the sub field

     2 : "42-50-31-FF-EF-37-32-39",               /sub/

This implies that there are two different "CRED_PSK"

(Maybe this has been discussed and I missed it....)

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Another approch that was discussed in the past was keeping a list of active G_X values, but this was abandoned due implementation complexities.

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body: Yes, I agree. I think having a list of active G_X is not worthy. Having two identifies should be fine. Or deriving two CRED_PSKs from the CRED_PSK: CRED_PSK_IR and CRED_PSK_RI

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body: I added a comment on this in the credential section, as well as in the security considerations

issues.title: CRED_PSK, sub field, and key derivation
issues.author: emanjon
labels: MUST be solved before formal analysis
issues.body:
```
{                                               /CCS/
   2 : "mydotbot",                               /sub/
   8 : {                                         /cnf/
     1 : {                                       /COSE_Key/
        1 : 4,                                   /kty/
        2 : h'0f',                               /kid/
       -1 : h'50930FF462A77A3540CF546325DEA214'  /k/
     }
   }
 }
```

- sub identifies I or R, not the PSK.

- sub cannot be included in 
`PRK_4e3m    = EDHOC_Extract( SALT_4e3m, CRED_PSK )
`

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body: Added an explanation in the Credential's section

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body:
I have a question regarding this sub field. So, if I understand correctly, the sub field allows to bind the authentication credential to some identity. This means that it would be different for the Initiator and the Responder, and they both need to know each other's in advance (?). 

However, the CRED_PSK is used in the derivation of PRK_4e3m, and this must be the same for both peers, which means that the sub field MUST not be included (how to do that, in terms of implementation, I do not see this part from the practical point of view). 
In addition, CRED_PSK is also used in TH_4. And this needs also to be the same for both, since it is used in PRK_out, K_4 and IV_4, so it should not be used there either (?)

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: This can be closed with the merge of #27

issues.title: Test vectors
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
Should have test vectors for EDHOC with PSK authentication. Does no need to be detailed as RFC 9529 but we should at a minimum have byte strings for

- CRED_PSK
- message_1
- message_2
- message_3
- message_4

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body: Done

issues.title: Issue in TH_3 Calculation
issues.author: francislopezg
issues.body:
Hi all, 
I have identified a potential issue in the calculation of Transcript Hash 3 (TH_3) in the draft specification. TH_3 is defined as follows:

 **TH_3 = H( TH_2, PLAINTEXT_2, CRED_PSK )**

TH_3 is then used to generate KEYSTREAM_3:

 **KEYSTREAM_3   = EDHOC_KDF( PRK_3e2m,    TBD, TH_3,  ID_CRED_PSK length )**

KEYSTREAM_3 is used by the Initiator to encrypt ID_CRED_PSK before sending it in message_3. Consequently, the Responder needs to derive the same KEYSTREAM_3 to decrypt ID_CRED_PSK when processing message_3.

The issue is that TH_3 already includes CRED_PSK. However, the Responder requires KEYSTREAM_3 to decrypt ID_CRED_PSK and determine which PSK should be used. This creates a circular dependency:
 
 1. To derive KEYSTREAM_3, the Responder must first compute TH_3.
 2. Computing TH_3 requires CRED_PSK, which depends on knowing the correct PSK.
 3. However, the Responder can only determine the correct PSK after decrypting ID_CRED_PSK using KEYSTREAM_3.

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body:
How about this?

TH_3 = H(TH_2, PLAINTEXT_2)
external_aad = << Enc(ID_CRED_PSK), TH_3, CRED_PSK >>

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body:
With the new format of message_3 would be:


TH_3 = H(TH_2, PLAINTEXT_2)
external_aad = << ID_CRED_PSK, TH_3, CRED_PSK >>

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body: I have fixed this in the text

issues.title: Should discuss ML-KEM
issues.author: emanjon
labels: MUST be solved before formal analysis
issues.body:
The text was not correct for ECDHE. I made commits to master making it correct for ECDHE.

The text should be updated to discuss both the current ECDHE cipher suites and future PQC cipher suites using e.g., ML-KEM. With ML-KEM, EDHOC-PSK would preserve all security properties against a quantum attacker.

issues.title: Less ECDHE
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
The following addition is ECDHE focused.

```
calculated from the the Initiator first.  Figure 1 shows the message flow of PSK Initiator's ephemeral public key G_X and the private key authentication method.	  corresponding to the Responder's public key G_Y, or vice verca
```

We should try to make the document agnostic to ECDHE or PQK KEMs.

issues.title: Resumption use of Exporter
issues.author: emanjon
labels: MUST be solved before formal analysis
issues.body:
```
to derive both CRED_PSK and ID_CRED_PSK:	
		 		
	6.1.  Identity protection	 	   CRED_PSK = EDHOC_Exporter( 2, h'', resumption_psk_length )	
		 	   ID_CRED_PSK = EDHOC_Exporter( 3, h'', id_cred_psk_length )
```

What is derived is the PSK and the PSK identifier, not the above structures.

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body: FIXED

issues.title: Guidelines specification for CRED_PSK
issues.author: ElsaLopez133
issues.body:
* "The authentication credential CRED_PSK substitutes CRED_I and CRED_R specified in [RFC9528], and, when applicable, MUST follow the same guidelines described in Section 3.5.2 and Section 3.5.3 of [RFC9528]." (NOT FIXED)
* Please spell out in this draft exactly what guidelines apply to CRED_PSK.

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body: Fixed

issues.title: Explain why MAC_2, and Signature_or_MAC_2 are not used
issues.author: ElsaLopez133

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body:
Would it be correct to say the following?

EDHOC-PSK replaces explicit MACs and Signatures with implicit authentication through key confirmation and successful AEAD decryption. MAC_2 is unnecessary because there is no responder credential (ID_CRED_R) involved, and PSK knowledge replaces asymmetric authentication. When using PSK, authentication is deferred and implicitly achieved in message_3 through the AEAD.

issues.title: Using the EDHOC + OSCORE request (RFC 9668)
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
If EDHOC PSK still allows the Initiator to compute PRK_out before sending EDHOC message_3, then it should be possible to use the EDHOC + OSCORE request specified in RFC 9668 [1] here too.

If so, that can be explicitly mentioned in this document. Fundamentally, it should be just like in RFC 9668, but of course with EDHOC message_3 consistent with the present EDHOC session using PSK-based authentication.

[1] https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc9668.html#section-3

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body: I added a new section including this optimization (section 7)

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Thanks!

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body: Should I simply refer to the RFC 9668 or should I describe it more extensively in the draft?

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
If it's just about using the EDHOC + OSCORE request as-is (which seems to be the case), then I believe that it should be fine to have high-level text like that in the new Section 7, without re-explaining that part of RFC 9668 in detail.

Even if there were minor things specific of using the EDHOC + OSCORE request with EDHOC PSK (I can't think of any at the moment), they could hopefully be described without needing to re-explain the whole thing.

issues.title: Acknowledge the CYPRESS project
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
Add to Acknowledgments:

"This work was supported partially by Vinnova - the Swedish Agency for Innovation Systems - through the EUREKA CELTIC-NEXT project CYPRESS."

issues.title: Some incorrect claims
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
>If AEAD verification fails, the Responder concludes either that the Initiator does not know the correct PSK...

This does not follow. What is true is that if AEAD verification succeeds, the Responder concludes that the Initiator possesses the PSK.

correct A => B <=> not B => not A
incorrect A => B <=> not A => not B

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
>    *  The Initiator can delete rPSK_i after having successfully verified
>       EDHOC message_4.  In this case, the Responder will have derived
>       the next rPSK_(i+1), which the Initiator can know for sure, upon
>       receiving EDHOC message_4.
> 
>    *  The Responder can delete rPSK_(i-1), if any, after having
>       successfully sent EDHOC message_4. 

This talks about message_4. Should talk about the forth message.

issues.title: More info on how EDHOC-PSK works in EAP
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
- Initial EAP-EDHOC
- Resumption for EAP-EDHOC
- Great replacement for EAP-PSK, which does not live up to current security practices.

I will write and commit some text later today

comments.body: Commited to main, plese review

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: I reviewed and added a commit. Does anyone else want to review or are we done?

pulls.title: Remove info label IANA
pulls.author: emanjon
pulls.body: The draft would need to create this registry, but I don't think it is needed. The requirement is that (mathod, info label) pairs don't collide. Info labels could be reused.

pulls.title: ID_CRED_PSK, PSK, CRED_I, and CRED_R
pulls.author: emanjon
pulls.body: Several changes are needed to the document to mitigate reflection attacks and to enable resumption. Additionally the terminology regarding ID_CRED_PSK, PSK, and CRED_x are fixed.

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body: Thanks for the pull request John. Looks good to me. I can start working on the test vectors (since they will be different now)

comments.author: ElsaLopez133
comments.body: Should I finally merge this pull request?
Why is this removed, accidental?
CRED_I and CRED_R aren't properly introduced yet.

* CRED_I and CRED_R are authentication credentials OF INITIATOR AND RESPONDER, RESPECTIVELY, associated with the PSK.
* "posterorily" is unknown term to me; "subsequently"?
Do we need to include the key?
CRED_x could be introduced earlier
Should we clarify that CRED_I is provisioned to R and v.v.?
Do you mean "is a reference to a kid" or "contains a kid"?
We have TH_4 defined in two places, should we make a reference instead?
Do you mean "... derive both rPSK and rKID"?
After resumption rKID will be stochastically unique. Should we require this also for the KID we start with (in the case of initial PSK authentication)?
> typo "same same"
Replace 0x5 with 0x05

reviews.author: gselander
reviews.body: I've made some comments. I can also propose changes, not before Wednesday.

comments.body: What do you mean they are not yet introduced?
My understanding is that COSE_Key would be one of the formats to store the PSK related information including the PSK itself but the CRED_I and CRED_R must not be sent in the ID_CRED_PSK
Yes, both should be provided as part of the PSK provisioning process
Yes, it should be rPSK and rKID
I think so , yes
with "normal operation" you mean "resumption operation"?
external_aad = << ID_CRED_PSK, TH_3, CRED_PSK >> should be also changed to external_aad = << ID_CRED_PSK, TH_3, CRED_I, CRED_R >>. It also defined in two places but I think it is necessary
Yes, I fixed this
I removed the double definition of TH_4 and added a reference in the second one. The external_aad is also corrected

reviews.author: francislopezg
reviews.body:
The Initiator is using suite 02 (as stated in the second byte of message_1), need to change it in the test vectors, where it says:

The initiator selects cipher suite 0. (...)
SUITES_I (CBOR Data Item) (1 byte)
00

Normative? Do we want to allow alternatives?

comments.body:
> > To authenticate the Responder and achieve mutual authentication, a fourth message is mandatory.
> 
> Normative? Do we want to allow alternatives?

I think it is correct as it says _a_ forth message. If I remember correctly it is described that this can be message_4 or an application protocol.

This need to be rewritten, either
The basis for the authentication is the Pre-Shared Key (PSK)
or
The basis for the security is the Pre-Shared Key (PSK) and the ephemeral key exchange

pulls.title: Resumption key management with fifth message
pulls.author: gselander

pulls.title: Fixing some details + some considerations about CREDs + fixing KEYSTREAM_3A derivation
pulls.author: francislopezg

comments.body: The old text suggested that the entire CRED_R and CRED_I structures remain identical across resumptions. This is not correct, since fields such as the kid (which refers to the PSK) may change. What remains identical are the underlying long-term credentials, not the CRED structures themselves.

Tag _11_ is already being used by the EDHOC_KeyUpdate function (see Appendix H of RFC9528) to define a new PRK_out: new PRK_out = EDHOC_KDF( old PRK_out, **11**, context, hash_length ). Thus, I think we will need to change it to _12_.

I think "MUST be provisioned out-of-band" is too strong. ID_CRED_PSK may include CRED_I, as a way to transport information about the identity (assuming there is an appropriate policy allowing this). I don't think we should have any normative text, but we can have security considerations about potential issues.

"CRED_I and CRED_R MUST refer to the same long-term credentials as in the initial EDHOC exchange"
I have problems with this change. We want to allow different formats for CRED_x, it may contain the PSK or not. The terminology is still that CRED_x are the "authentication credenitals" and ID_CRED_PSK is referring to the authentcation credentials. Saying that CRED_x refers to credentials therefore becomes confusing. I think the original formulation is correct: We discussed different options for maintaining disambiguation and agreed on the simple method to always use the initial CRED_I and CRED_R, and this applies even in resumption when PSK and kid are changed.
Understood. Thank you for the clarification.
I don't think there is a problem using label 11 since the keys are different, but since KEYSTREAM_3A is a new object defined in this document it doesn't hurt to use a new label.

pulls.title: security considerations
pulls.author: ElsaLopez133
pulls.body:
We should list the claimed properties, including Confidentiality (and PFS), Mutual Authentication and explicit key confirmation, Downgrade Protection, Cryptographic Protection, EAD Protection and Identity Protection.
I was following the requirements of RFC9528 and those in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-lake-reqs/04/
